| network = [[Oxygen (TV channel)|Oxygen]] | first_aired = {{start date|2006|12|5}} | last_aired = present | num_seasons = 7 | num_episodes = 130 | list_episodes = | related = ''[[Bad Girls Road Trip]]''
''[[Love Games: Bad Girls Need Love Too]]'' | website = http://bad-girls-club.oxygen.com/ | production_website = http://www.bunim-murray.com/ }} '''''Bad Girls Club''''' is an American [[reality television]] series created by [[Jonathan Murray]] for [[Oxygen (TV channel)|Oxygen]]. The show centers on seven mischievous and rebellious women with different backgrounds and personalities who have a number of [[psychological]] and behavioral problems. They are introduced to the show to change their pernicious behavior and accomplish specific goals. The cast, deemed "bad girls", are asked to maintain and respect rules applied to them before enjoying a luxurious mansion and lifestyle for three months. Their lives inside â and outside â of the house are chronicled and recorded by the [[production team]]. The format of the show changed from antecedent seasons. If a "bad girl" had broke a rule she will be evicted from the show and will be replaced â if early in the season â by a new "bad girl". There have been six complete seasons of ''The Bad Girls Club'', with the [[The Bad Girls Club (season 8)|eighth season]] scheduled to air January 23, 2012. The [[The Bad Girls Club (season 4)|fourth season]] had the highest ratings in Bad Girls' history, becoming the show's "breakthrough season".{{Cite web |url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2010/02/10/more-ratings-highs-for-oxygens-bad-girls-club/41693 |title=More ratings highs for Oxygen's "Bad Girls Club" |author=Robert Seidman |date=10 February 2010 |work=TV By The Numbers |publisher=|accessdate=9 January 2011}} ''The Bad Girls Club'' is broadcast in five countries. The show received negative reviews from critics who believe the show promotes violence by adolescents viewers. Several cast-members also made controversial remarks which outraged many viewers. There have been three [[spin-off (media)|spin-off]]s of ''The Bad Girls Club''. [[Love Games: Bad Girls Need Love Too]], where alumni cast-members seek true love, has gained high ratings. Oxygen has also released a [[mobile game]], [[comic strip]] and [[merchandise]] to promote the show. Of the 61 contestants, [[Kerry Harvick]] (of [[The Bad Girls Club (season 1)|season one]]) became a successful [[Country music|country singer]] after the show.{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/p684674/biography |title=Kerry Harvick's biography |author=Steve Leggett |date=22 September 2011 |work=[[Allmusic]] |publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]] }} Tanisha Thomas (of [[The Bad Girls Club (season 2)|season two]]) later hosted Oxygen's ''OxygenLive!'' and the [[Love Games: Bad Girls Need Love Too (season 2)|second season]] of "Love Games: Bad Girls Need Love Too". Amber Meade, Amber Buell, Sarah Michaels, Kendra Jones, Natalie Nunn, and Lea Beaulieu have competed in the "Love Games: Bad Girls Need Love Too" series. == Format == The show follows seven rebellious women{{cite web|last=Frankel|first=Danielle|title=Oxygen renews 'Bad Girls Club'|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118002046|work=Variety|accessdate=15 November 2011}} who are between the ages of 21 and 27.{{cite web|last=Reynolds|first=Mike|title=Oxygen Orders Third Season Of 'Bad Girls'|url=http://www.multichannel.com/article/134039-Oxygen_Orders_Third_Season_Of_Bad_Girls_.php|work=multichannel|accessdate=28 September 2011}} They co-exist in a mansion for three months, as cameramen record their behavior in and out of the house. The girls, deemed "bad girls", come from different backgrounds and have personality, psychological, and behavioral problems.{{cite web|last=Hwang|first=Kellie|title=Bad Girls Club casting for season 8|url=http://www.azcentral.com/thingstodo/bars/articles/2011/05/19/20110519bad-girls-club-love-games-casting-tempe-hooters.html|work=The Arizona Republic|accessdate=28 September 2011}}{{cite web|last=Lowry|first=Brian|title=The Bad Girls Club|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117932242?refCatId=32|work=Variety|accessdate=15 November 2011}} The "bad girls" try to cope with one another and change their promiscuous behavior to become role models for young women. Some cast members try to accomplish specific goals.{{cite news|last=Hesse|first=Monica|title='Queen Bees': Do You Catch More Eyes With Honey?|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/1508559961.html?dids=1508559961:1508559961&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jul+11%2C+2008&author=Monica+Hesse+-+Washington+Post+Staff+Writer&pub=The+Washington+Post&desc='Queen+Bees'%3A+Do+You+Catch+More+Eyes+With+Honey%3F&pqatl=google|accessdate=28 September 2011|newspaper=Washington Post|date=11 July 2008}}{{cite news|title="Bad Girls Club" Reunion Drama|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/03/24/entertainment/main6329855.shtml|accessdate=15 November 2011|date=1 June 2010}} Throughout the show, the "bad girls" must adapt to the frequent mood and behavior changes of their roommates.{{cite book|last=Oppliger|first=Patrice A.|title=Girls gone skank : the sexualization of girls in American culture|year=2008|publisher=McFarland & Co.|location=Jefferson, N.C.|isbn=0786435224|pages=258}}{{cite web|last=Lowry|first=Brian|title=First season of 'The Bad Girls Club'|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117932242?refCatId=32|work=Variety|accessdate=28 September 2011}} They must also obey rules that were presented to them prior to their arrival. If they engage in violence towards other roommates or breach other [[production team]] rules, they may be evicted due to the show's [[zero tolerance]] policy. The "bad girls" must also undergo interviews in the diary room and confessionals. In most cases, the "bad girls" divide into cliques, create havoc, book parties in night clubs, and shop for groceries while attempting to maintain their personal lives. The "bad girls" are allowed to contact their families and friends using a computer connected to a big screen television. The use of televisions or cell phones is prohibited in the house. Bullying and "tag teaming" (when multiple cast members intimidate another cast member) are seen throughout the series. On some occasions, a "bad girl" has departed the show because of their detrimental roommates, isolation, growing problems at home, court proceedings, or own [[wikt:Narcissism|narcissism]]. In rare occasions, multiple "bad girls" may wish to leave the show. The only seasons to have multiple cast-members to leave the show were [[The Bad Girls Club (season 1)|season one]] (2006), [[The Bad Girls Club (season 5)|season five]] (2010) and [[The Bad Girls Club (season 6)|season six]] (2011). If a "bad girl" departs early in the season, a "replacement bad girl" is introduced within one or two episodes. In most cases, the "replacement bad girl" is treated reprehensible. In rare occasions, a "replacement bad girl" may leave voluntarily. The only season to have this done was in the fifth season. In the [[The Bad Girls Club (season 7)|seventh season]], cast-member Cheyenne Evans was exempted from the show by Tiara Hodge. This became the first event that a "replacement"/"bad girl" is removed from the show involuntarily and not removed from the show by producers.
A Bad Girl knows what she wants and how to get it. She makes her own way, makes her own rules and she makes no apologies. A Bad Girl blazes her own trail and removes obstacles from her path. A Bad Girl fights and forces her way to the top with style and beauty. A Bad Girl believes in jumping first and looking later. People will love you. People will hate you. Others will secretly wish to be you. A Bad Girl is you.{{Cite web |url=http://bad-girls-club.oxygen.com/about-the-bad-girls-club |title=About the "Bad Girls Club" |author=|date= |work=|publisher=Oxygen.com |accessdate=6 October 2010}}
Above is the ''Bad Girls Club'' [[creed]] which was introduced in the [[The Bad Girls Club (season 3)|third season]] of the ''Bad Girls Club''. === Season's 1 and 2 === The format for the first season of the ''Bad Girls Club'' was contradistinctive from subsequent seasons.{{cite journal|last=Fernandez|first=Julio|title=Bad Girls? Or Bad Wast??|journal=Pierce County Herald|date=16 April 2011|accessdate=28 September 2011}} The age differences in the cast for season one was 21 and 31. The use of "nicknames" were not introduced until the third season of the ''Bad Girls Club''. Season one also saw the first time that a rare occasion of multiple "replacement bad girls" enters the show. Although there were distinctiveness in season one, the rules that are currently present in the show's format existed throughout subsequent seasons. Another format that continued was the way the show debuted; which allowed viewers to unfold a physical altercation leading to the first eviction of the season. In the [[The Bad Girls Club (season 2)|second season]], the format of the show changed drastically. The maximum age requirements to apply dropped from 35 to 27. The cast of season two were given mandatory [[Voluntary association|non-profit job]]s to help them build a [[work ethic]] along with stability of being dependent on others, such as [[teamwork]] and commitment for success in later life.{{cite journal|last=Williams|first=James|title=Ratings Success for Oxygen's Bad Girls Club|journal=The Cheney Free Press|date=18 October 2009|accessdate=28 September 2011}} Quitting the job or failure to attend resulted in mandatory removal from the show. The girls were given the jobs of planning, [[decision making]], and build [[cooperation]]. Season two became the first and only season of the ''Bad Girls Club'' to perform this and also was the final season to air 30-minute episodes. === Live shows === On August 3, 2010, during the OxygenLive TV recap episode, the show combined Facebook and Twitter with a live broadcast. Fans submited opinions and comments about the show and its cast which were aired during the 10 p.m hour. In January 2011, Oxygen released ''OxygenLive!'' an [[online show|online]] [[talk show]] hosted by Tanisha Thomas (of season two). It was broadcast after [[The Bad Girls Club (season 6)|season six]] debuted on Oxygen. The talk show centered the cast of season six and occasionally alumni "bad girls". Thomas asked several questions to the girls to prompt rumors and confessions.{{Cite web |url=http://www.oxygenlive.com/ |title=OxygenLive.com |author=|date= |work=|publisher=Oxygen.com |accessdate=6 2011}} |TBA |[[Las Vegas, Nevada]] |} == U.S. television ratings == The third season of ''Bad Girls Club'' became the first Oxygen series to average more than 1 million viewers per episode. The third season also was among the leaders in basic cable in Oxygen's core demo of women 18-34, where it averaged 397,000 viewers. By the fifth season of ''Bad Girls Club'', the show became the first program to draw 2 million viewers on a Tuesday. It also had set a record for Oxygen and garnered a 67% increased in the 18-49 demo compared to the third season.{{cite web|last=Weisman|first=Jon|title='Bad Girls Club' packs for Miami|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118014122|work=Variety|accessdate=15 November 2011}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:19%;" rowspan="2"| Season ! style="width:7%;" rowspan="2"| Timeslot ([[Eastern Time Zone|ET]]) ! style="width:7%;" rowspan="2"| Airings ! colspan=2| Premiered ! colspan=3| Ended ! style="width:5%; background:#ffdead;" rowspan="2"| A18-49 ! style="width:5%; background:#ffdead;" rowspan="2"| W18-34 ! style="width:5%; background:#ffdead;" rowspan="2"| H/H Share ! style="width:5%; background:#ffdead;" rowspan="2"| Highest rated episode

|author=[[Perez Hilton]] |date=22 September 2011 |work= |publisher=[[PerezHilton.com]] }}{{cite web |url=http://www.queerty.com/someone-please-throw-a-drink-in-bad-girls-club-new-orleans-tashas-face-20110826/ |title=Someone Please Throw a Drink in Bad Girls Club: New Orleans Tashaâs Face |author=Brody Brown |date=22 September 2011 |work=26 August 2011 |publisher=Queerty }}{{cite news |title=Taylor Lautnerâs Gay Kiss, The Good Wife, Magneto in Drag, Big Brother And More! |author= |url=http://www.queerty.com/taylor-lautners-gay-kiss-the-good-wife-magneto-in-drag-big-brother-and-more-20110829/ |newspaper=Queerty |date=29 August 2011 |accessdate=22 September 2011}} Mary Mitchell of ''[[Sun Times]]'' stated that the show was "[...] hazardous to the female psyche".{{cite news |title=âSpongeBobâ should be just the start of warnings of unhealthy TV |author=Mary Mitchell |url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/mitchell/7658166-417/spongebob-should-be-just-the-start-of-warnings-of-unhealthy-tv.html |newspaper=[[Sun Times]] |date=14 September 2011 |accessdate=22 September 2011}} Mitchell also stated that "Just like some teens try to emulate rappers in their dress and behavior, the same is true for "bad girls [club]." She also instated that the show gives a "distorted picture" of how to live the good life. She then called the cast "wannabes" who are "sleeping in a mansion they can't pay for". Mitchell believes that most people know that the cast are living "a bogus lifestyle" while also stating that the ''Bad Girls Club''{{'}}s message is "disturbing". Many adolescents have emulated ''The Bad Girls Club'', a negative consequence that many locals try to prohibit the viewing of the show.{{cite news |title=Atlanta Teachers: Students Emulating Reality TV Drama |author=Johan Thomas |url=http://newsone.com/nation/jothomas/emulating-reality-tv-drama/ |newspaper=NewsOne |date=26 August 2011 |accessdate=22 September 2011}} The show also received negative criticism from African-American viewers, believing that the show is "not what being a black woman is all about."{{cite news |title=Black teenagers defy pop culture portrayals |author=Laura Sessions Stepp |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/OPINION/09/06/stepp.black.teens/ |newspaper=[[CNN]] |date=7 September 2011 |accessdate=22 September 2011}} Mary Chase of ''Reflector'' stated that "[...] there are several TV programs [including ''Bad Girls Club'' that are] devoted to acting as trashy and mean as possible".{{cite news |title=Wedding hype replaces institutionâs meaning |author=Mary Chase Breedlove |url=http://www.reflector-online.com/opinion/wedding-hype-replaces-institution-s-meaning-1.2616448 |newspaper=Reflector |date=30 August 2011 |accessdate=22 September 2011}} The ''[[New York Daily News]]'' reported that the ''Bad Girls Club'' was the equivalent of [[pro wrestling]].{{cite news|title='Bad Girls Club' are back in real-life fright club|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2008-12-02/entertainment/17912266_1_bad-girls-club-oxygen-show|accessdate=27 September 2011|newspaper=New York Daily News|date=2 December 2008}} Kris De Leon of [[BuddyTV]] said that "[The show] is crude, rude and pointless, but sort of addictive to some people."{{cite web|last=De Leon|first=Kris|title='Bad Girls Club' Season 3 Returns with Bolder Bad Girls|url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/bad-girls-club/bad-girls-club-season-3-return-24991.aspx|work=BuddyTV|accessdate=27 September 2011}} Brian Lowry of ''Variety'' noted that the producers made the "wrong decision" when they created the show. Brian Lowry of Variety believed that the cast of ''Bad Girls Club'' auditioned for the show for their "[...] 15 minutes of fame [...]". Lowry stated that ''Bad Girls Club'' "... arrived a little late in this game, on a channel lacking the kind of exposure or public footprint to qualify the show even as the stuff guilty pleasures are made of ..." Lowry believed the show "loses" and Oxygen attracts viewers who generally gets drunk at bars and makes a scene. Lowry also stated that "... viewed that way, maybe it's time to "BAG" these bad-attitude girls and beat a hasty retreat back to the real world ..." Anita Gates of ''[[The New York Times]]'' referred to the ''Bad Girls Club'' as "... a great argument for bringing back programming with actors ..." Gates had believed that the "average emotional age" had appeared to be 15, while contrasting the girls' ages. Gates stated that the "... unpleasant villains cancel one another out and actually make badness uninteresting ...", while commenting on their behavior stating that they may not be "bad enough". Gates finalized her review stating that ''Bad Girls Club'' is the on-location equivalent of [[The Jerry Springer Show]].{{cite news|last=Gates|first=Anita|title=Graduating From Bad to Worse as an Adventure in Self-Help|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/05/arts/television/05gate.html|accessdate=15 November 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=5 December 2006}} Kelly West of [[Cinemablend]] stated that ''Bad Girls Club'' is "so much fun to watch".{{cite web|last=West|first=Kelly|title=TV Review: The Bad Girls Club - Season 2 Premiere|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/television/TV-Review-The-Bad-Girls-Club-Season-2-Premiere-7612.html|work=Cinemablend|accessdate=15 November 2011}} == Controversies == === Season 4 === During the premiere episode of the [[The Bad Girls Club (season 4)|fourth season]], "Off The Wall", Natalie Nunn and Annie Andersen were talking amongst themselves on which [[night club]] to attend. Nunn told Anderson that [[Chris Brown (American singer)|Chris Brown]] was at a night club that Nunn wanted to attend. She also asked Anderson if she was a fan. Anderson replied that she wasn't because of the [[Chris Brown (American singer)#Domestic violence case|domestic violence case]] that Brown was involved in. Nunn immediately went on the defense for Brown stating "Who cares, [[Rihanna]] was a punk bitch, and she got her ass whop for a reason".{{cite web|title=PP2G gossip;Say What: Mr. Steal Yo Girl Trey Songz gespot met Amber Rose in #Ghana, #WWW Waar was Wiz|url=http://www.pp2g.com/News/12479/PP2G-gossipSay-What-Mr-Steal-Yo-Girl-Trey-Songz-gespot-met-Amber-Rose-in-Ghana-WWW-Waar-was-Wiz|work=PP2G|accessdate=27 September 2011|language=[[Dutch language|Ductch]]}} Nunn also stated that Rihanna is a "crazy bitch" and told Anderson that she doesn't know her, like Nunn does. When the episode had aired, Brown reportedly stated that he doesn't know who Nunn was, which was questioned by Nunn during the reunion show.{{Cite web |url=http://bossip.com/173887/bossip-exclusive-natalie-nunn-says-chris-brown-is-lying-we-chopped-it-up-and-he-chopped-it-down/ |title=*Bossip Exclusive* Natalie Nunn says Chris Brown is Lyingâ¦ We Chopped it Up and He Chopped it Down!!! |author=Bossip Staff |date=31 October 2009 |work=|publisher=[[Bossip]] |accessdate=6 February 2011}}{{cite web|title=Chris Brown â neue Freundin aus Erziehungscamp|url=http://www.viply.de/?p=29881|work=Viply.com|accessdate=27 September 2011|language=[[German language|German]]}}{{cite web|title=Chris Brown: neue Freundin?|url=http://www.songtext.net/news/chris-brown-neue-freundin/32168|accessdate=27 September 2011|language=German}} Nunn then stated that Brown made that comment, because the cast of the show was not unveiled yet. [[Perez Hilton]], the host of the reunion, had asked Nunn if Rihanna had confronted her after her comment that she had made towards her. Nunn answered yes, stating that the two had reportedly been arguing during a dinner party in New York City.{{Cite episode |title=Episode 15 "Reunion Part I: Breaking Point" Season 4 |episodelink= |url= |accessdate= |series=15 |serieslink= |credits= |network=[[Oxygen (TV channel)|Oxygen]] |station= |city=Los Angeles |airdate=16 March 2010 |began= |ended= |season=4 |seriesno=415 |number= |minutes=60}} During the reunion, Nunn stated that she and Brown had a "[[wikt:fling|fling]]" prior to the show.{{Cite episode |title=Episode 1 "Off The Wall" Season 4 |episodelink= |url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/Bad-Girls-2009/episode-1-season-4/wall/284911 |accessdate=30 November 2009 |series=1 |serieslink= |credits= |network=[[Oxygen (TV channel)|Oxygen]] |station= |city=Los Angeles |airdate=1 December 2009 |began= |ended= |season=4 |seriesno=401 |number= |minutes=60}}{{Cite episode |title=Episode 16 "Reunion Part II: It Ain't Over" Season 4 |episodelink= |url= |accessdate= |series=16 |serieslink= |credits= |network=[[Oxygen (TV channel)|Oxygen]] |station= |city=Los Angeles |airdate=23 March 2010 |began= |ended= |season=4 |seriesno=416 |number= |minutes=60}} Shortly before the reunion was over, Nunn expressed that she does not condone [[domestic violence]] and apologized if her comment had enraged fans and other people who had gone through domestic violence. === Season 5 === {{Quote box |quote = "I had no idea where I was and [I] had to go to the ER over night. They later discovered someone put [[Phencyclidine|PCP]] in my drink. They can't show it on the show because then that guy could sue for [[Defamation|slander]]. I am honestly really upset they didnt explain that [during] the show. I think its really messed up how the entire story [wasn't ever] shown [on air], whatever. DONE!" |source = Kristen Kelly expressing an incident that ensued prior to her altercation with Lea. |width = 20% |align = right }} During the episode "The Wicked Witch Of Key West", Kristen Kelly was at a bar with Christina Marie Hopkins. While there, a stranger offered to buy drinks for the two girls. While doing so, the guy added [[Phencyclidine|PCP]] hypnotic sleeping pills which made Kelly to be [[Toxication|intoxicated]]. Kelly claimed she suffered bruises on her body when the guy grabbed her and handled her roughly. Kelly also reported that the producers of the show did not want to air the guy on television in order from being sued. She also blamed the drug for her reasoning behind hitting another cast-member, Lea Beaulieu in the face, resulting in a physical altercation.{{Cite web |url=http://perezhilton.com/2010-11-17-kristen-claims-she-was-drugged-in-fight-with-lea |title=Bad Girl Kristen Claims She Was Drugged During Fight With Lea |author=[[Perez Hilton]] |date=17 November 2010 |work=|publisher=[[PerezHilton.com]] |accessdate=6 February 2011}} One of Christina Marie Hopkins' friend recorded her intoxicated making [[racial slurs]] about an African American woman who had threatened her. The video surfaced on the Internet and outraged many people.{{cite web |url=http://www.tmz.com/2011/05/13/bad-girls-club-oxygen-network-christina-hopkins-racist-rant-mexican-food/ |title=Oxygen Network BANS 'Bad Girls Club' Star |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=22 September 2011 |work= |publisher=[[TMZ.com]]}} Oxygen reported to [[TMZ.com]] that Hopkins will never appear on their channel again. TMZ.com reported that roommate Ashley Cheatham sent Hopkins a hate text visible to the world. In it, Cheatham told Hopkins to "[...] do us all a favor and go kill yourself".{{cite web |url=http://www.tmz.com/2011/05/14/bad-girls-club-ashley-cheatam-christina-hopkins-n-word-racist-rant-video-go-kill-yourself/ |title='Bad Girl' Star RIPS Ranting Castmate -- Kill Yourself! |author= |date=22 September 2011 |work= |publisher=TMZ.com }} After her incident, Hopkins released an apology letter stating her reasons for the slurs.{{cite web |url=http://www.tmz.com/2011/05/13/christina-hopkins-bad-girls-club-racist-video-rant-apology-letter/ |title='Bad Girl' Issues Apology Letter -- Odd Delivery |author= |date=22 September 2011 |work= |publisher=TMZ.com }} After the season five had wrapped, Catya Washington was sentenced to jail for possession of a concealed weapon and illegal use of drugs.{{cite web|last=Finn|first=Natalie|title=How ClichÃ©! Bad Girls Club Member Arrested|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/how_clicheacute_bad_girls_club_member/209653|work=E! News|accessdate=27 September 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.tmz.com/2010/11/04/bad-girls-club-catya-washington-arrested-cocaine-ecstacy-gun-mushrooms/ |title='Bad Girls Club' Chick Busted -- Coke, Ecstasy, Gun |author= |date=22 September 2011 |work= |publisher=TMZ.com }}{{cite news|last=Carlin|first=DeGuerin Miller|title=Catya Washington from "Bad Girls Club: Miami" Arrested on Drug Charges, Says Report|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-20021909-504083.html|accessdate=28 September 2011|newspaper=CBS News|date=5 November 2010}}{{cite web|last=Johnson|first=Lynda|title=Reality TV Star Catya Washington Drug Bust|url=http://www.nationalledger.com/pop-culture-news/reality-tv-star-catya-washingt-274785.shtml|work=Nationalledger|accessdate=28 September 2011}} However, several days later, Washington was sentenced back to jail after Washington struck the wife of a guy who Washington was dating and sprayed [[mace (spray)|mace]] in the wife's face.{{cite web |url=http://www.tmz.com/2010/11/05/bad-girls-club-catya-washington-arrest-mace-car-accident-philadelphia/ |title='Bad Girls' Chick -- Alleged Car-Crashing Face-Macer |author= |date=22 September 2011 |work= |publisher=TMZ.com }} She was then charged with [[aggravated assault]], inflicting serious bodily injury, possession of an instrument of crime (mace), and recklessly endangering another person. Washington's bail was set at $500,000, though her family raised the funds to bail her out.{{cite web |url=http://www.tmz.com/person/more-stories/catya-washington |title=Jailed 'Bad Girls' Chick -- Family Plots Bailout Scheme |author= |date=22 September 2011 |work= |publisher=TMZ.com }} She was then released under [[house arrest]].{{cite web |url=http://www.tmz.com/2010/11/22/bad-girls-club-catya-washington-lindsay-lohan-ankle-bracelet-drug-alcohol-probation/ |title='Bad Girls' Chick -- Equipped with Tracking Device |author= |date=22 September 2011 |work= |publisher=TMZ.com }} However, Washington was arrested again because of "[[Probation violation|outstanding bench warrant]]" several days after her release.{{cite web |url=http://www.tmz.com/2011/01/04/bad-girls-star-catya-washington-jail-slammer-warrant-violation/ |title='Bad Girls Club' Star -- Thrown Back In The Slammer |author= |date=22 September 2011 |work= |publisher=TMZ.com }} Washington was released from jail with an extended house arrest curfew.{{cite web |url=http://www.tmz.com/2011/01/10/bad-girl-catya-washington-freebird-for-now-released-prison-house-arrest-drug-possesion/ |title='Bad Girls Club' Chick -- A Second Chance at Freedom |author= |date=22 September 2011 |work= |publisher=TMZ.com }} === Season 6 === During production of season six, residents from [[Sherman Oaks]] (Los Angeles) complained that noise levels and swearing was extremely unbearable and inappropriate for them and their children to listen to during the night.{{cite news |title='Bad Girls Club' Experience May Hinder Local Production Push |author=Doug Kriegel |url=http://shermanoaks.patch.com/articles/bad-girls-club-experience-may-hinder-local-production-push#video-3837952 |newspaper=Sherman Oaks Patch |date=28 December 2010 |accessdate=23 April 2011}} Residents from Sherman Oaks called [[Law enforcement in Los Angeles County|local enforcements]] four-five times to defused the corruptions, the girls were showcasing, in the middle of the night. Clarissa Keller, a local Sherman Oaks resident, complained that she has a six-year-old son and didn't want him to listen to the swearing, she went as far as creating a [[Initiative|petition drive]] to ban all production companies in the Sherman Oaks hills. Location managers and production crew declined to discuss the neighbors complaints. The ''Bad Girls Club'' permit (FilmLA) announced that the entire production was to abide the "minimum outdoor activity noise" rule, whereas, neighbors state otherwise that the show did not keep noise levels at a low range. The house for season six was rented for $20,000 a month, the man who owns the house told Sherman Oaks that he will not allow this type of production to rent his home in the future. === Season 7 === On March 13, 2011, TMZ.com reported that the cast were banned from at least eight clubs due to the clubs "not wanting to be associated with the show's bad image". The cast were also not allowed to attend [[Pierre Thomas (American football)|Pierre Thomas]]'s [[New Orleans Mardi Gras|Mardi Gras]] party at the The Metropolitan Night Club.{{cite news|url=http://www.tmz.com/2011/03/13/bad-girls-club-new-orleans-trashy-night-club-banned-bad-reputation-bars-metropolitan-pierre-thomas/|title=âBad Girls Clubâ -- Too âTrashyâ for New Orleans|work=[[TMZ.com]]|publisher=[[Time Warner]]|date=13 March 2011|accessdate=28 May 2011}} On April 12, 2011 cast member Tasha Malek complained to an on-duty police officer outside the ''Bad Girls'' house about the conduct of her fellow cast member Nastasia Townsend. She claimed that Townsend placed her personal belongings into a garbage bag while telling her "she needed to leave the house" and that the incident escalated into an altercation.{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2011/04/summonses_issued_to_two_cast_m.html|title=Two 'Bad Girls' cited for fight on Kenner set of TV show|last=Ross|first=Bob|work=[[The Times-Picayune]]|publisher=[[Advance Publications]]|date=15 April 2011|accessdate=17 April 2011}} The two were issued [[summons]] by the police for [[disturbing the peace]] and [[disorderly conduct]].{{cite web|url=http://media.nola.com/politics/other/bad.girls.pdf|title=Kenner Police Report|publisher=The Times-Picayune|date=12 April 2011|accessdate=17 April 2011}} Tasha Malek released a statement saying that "she doesn't think being gay is right". {{note|2|[II]}} [[U.S. state]] abbreviations can be found [[List of U.S. state abbreviations#List|here]]. == Spin-offs == === ''Bad Girls Road Trip'' === {{main|Bad Girls Road Trip}} The ''Bad Girls Road Trip'' premiered on June 12, 2007. The show centered season one cast-members Zara Sprankle, Aimee Landi, and Leslie Ramsue, who toured their respective hometowns, in search for casting opportunities for the second season of ''The Bad Girls Club.'' While on their roadtrip they also visited their former housemates.{{Cite web |url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1001468/ |title=Bad Girls Road Trip |author=|date= |work=|publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]] |accessdate=6 February 2011}} ''Bad Girls Road Trip'' aired six episodes before it was canceled on July 24, 2007. === ''Love Games: Bad Girls Need Love Too'' === {{main|Love Games: Bad Girls Need Love Too}} ''Love Games: Bad Girls Need Love Too'' premiered on March 16, 2010. The show's premise follows three alumni "bad girls" from seasons' past who are searching for true love. The [[Love Games: Bad Girls Need Love Too (season 1)|first season]] was hosted by comedian [[Bret Ernst]], which consisted of eight one-hour episodes. The three "bad girls" that were searching for love were Amber Meade and Sarah Michaels both from the third season of the ''Bad Girls Club'' and Kendra Jones from the fourth season of the ''Bad Girls Club''. The season finale was on April 27, 2010. The show had become a ratings success.{{cite web |url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/02/02/oxygens-love-games-bad-girls-need-love-too-returns-april-18/81303/ |title=Oxygen's "Love Games: Bad Girls Need Love Too" Returns April 18 |author=Bill Gorman |date=22 September 2011 |work=TVbyTheNumbers |publisher=Zap2it }} Oxygen renewed the show for a [[Love Games: Bad Girls Need Love Too (season 2)|second run]].{{Cite news | url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2010/01/10/oxygen-plays-matchmaker-with-love-games-bad-girls-need-love-too-in-march-2010/38294 |title=Oxygen Plays Matchmaker With "Love Games: Bad Girls Need Love Too" In March 2010 | publisher=TVbytheNumbers.com | work=[[Oxygen (TV channel)|Oxygen]] | date=10 January 2010 | accessdate=11 January 2010}} Tanisha Thomas (from season one of the ''Bad Girls Club'') was the host for season two. Natalie Nunn (season four), Amber Buell (season three) and Lea Beaulieu (season five) competed in the second season for true love.{{Cite web |url=http://love-games.oxygen.com/lovegames/photos/meet-the-cast-season-2 |title=Meet the Cast: Season 2 |author=|date= |work=|publisher=[[Oxygen.com]] |accessdate=6 February 2011}} The show premiered on April 18, 2011. The second season aired eight one-hour episodes before the show ended on June 13, 2011. Oxygen announced that the [[Love Games: Bad Girls Need Love Too (season 3)|third season]] will air on December 5, 2011. Kori Koether, Sydney Steinfeldt and Judi Jai are said to compete in the third installation of the show. Both Koether and Steinfeldt were contestants on season six of ''The Bad Girls Club'', while Jai was a contestant on the seventh season.{{cite web|title=Love Games:Bad Girls Need Love Too returns on December 5|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2011/10/03/oxygen-media-plays-matchmaker-again-when-love-games-bad-girls-need-love-too-returns-on-december-5-at-10pm-et-pt-188204/20111003oxygen01/|work=Thefutoncritic|accessdate=4 October 2011}} === ''Bad Girls Club: Flo Gets Married'' === ''Bad Girls Club: Flo Gets Married'' is a one-hour special that centers around season four cast-member [[Florina "Flo" Kaja]] who had a traditional [[Albanians|Albanian]] [[Culture of Albania#Weddings as part of Albanian culture|wedding]], and pregnancy. The special aired on Oxygen on February 28, 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2011/02/09/oxygen-medias-bad-girl-is-entering-uncharted-territory-in-bad-girls-club-flo-gets-married-on-february-28-at-9-pm-et-pt-383504/20110209oxygen01/|title=Oxygen Media's "Bad Girl" Is Entering Uncharted Territory in "Bad Girls Club: Flo Gets Married" on February 28 at 9 pm ET/PT|publisher=The Futon Critic|date=9 February 2011|accessdate=11 February 2011}} It was watched by 859,000 viewers.{{Cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/03/01/monday-cable-ratings-wwe-raw-leads-night-skins-being-human-rise-pretty-little-liars-cake-boss-more/84108|title=Monday Cable Ratings: 'WWE Raw' Leads Night; 'Skins,' 'Being Human' Rise + 'Pretty Little Liars,' 'Cake Boss' & More|last=Gorman|first=Bill|work=TVbyTheNumbers|publisher=[[Zap2it]]|date=1 March 2011|accessdate=1 March 2011}} === ''Tanisha Gets Married'' === A docu-series tentatively titled ''Tanisha Gets Married'' is set to air in 2012. It follows ''Bad Girls Club'' season two cast member Tanisha Thomas as she prepares for her wedding. The series was produced by 495 Productions with [[SallyAnn Salsano]] serving as executive producer.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jersey-shore-tanisha-thomas-bad-girls-club-oxygen-243615|title='Jersey Shore' Boss Sells Tanisha Thomas Wedding Vehicle to Oxygen|last=Rose|first=Lacey|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=4 October 2011|accessdate=8 October 2011}} == Other media and merchandise == In 2007, Oxygen released a [[3G]] [[mobile game]] based on ''The Bad Girls Club'' in partnership with [[Artificial Life, Inc]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.multichannel.com/article/CA6462175.html|author=Reynolds, Mike|title=Oxygen Announces Mobile Game, Local-Ad-Sales Promo|publisher=Multichannel News|date=23 July 2007}}{{Cite web|url=http://news.softpedia.com/news/The-Bad-Girls-Club-3G-Make-Sexy-Mobile-Game-61232.shtml|author=Balan, Elena|title=The Bad Girls Club 3G Makes Sexy Mobile Game|publisher=[[Softpedia]]|date=27 July 2007}} The 3G game featured 3D [[Avatar (computing)|avatar]]s based on the Bad Girls, as well as photo-realistic locations based on the actual house. "The Bad Girls Club collection", which began in 2008 with the start of the [[The Bad Girls Club (season 3)|third season]] of ''Bad Girls Club'', is an [[Online shopping|online boutique]] that fans of the show can order via Oxygen's website, ''Shopoholic.com''. Oxygen has released a series of pants, shirts and sweaters, mostly decor of the Bad Girls Club logo attached. The series of jewelry, kitchen utensils, beach wear, pillows, blankets, and women underwear also includes the logo design. The store, mostly women accessories, also has a line of boxers for men.{{Cite web |url=http://www.shopoholic.com/eSource/PK/ecom/eSource/items/items-2-S1-lV1BadGirlsCl-lV2OXY.aspx?store=OXYv3 |title=Shopoholic - Bad Girls Club collection |author=|date= |work=|publisher=[[Oxygen.com]] |accessdate=6 February 2011}} In September 2011, Oxygen released an online illustrated comic strip of the ''Bad Girls Club'' which featured Tanisha Thomas. The comic strip, which is downloadable and can be played on Facebook, was titled "The Adventures of the BGC".{{cite web |url=http://bad-girls-club.oxygen.com/ |title=The Adventures of the BGC |author= |date=21 September 2011 |work=Oxygen |publisher=Oxygen.com }} == See also == *[[Women's interest channel|List of Women interest shows]] *[[List of reality television programs]] *[[List of reality television programs with LGBT cast members]] *[[List of television shows set in Los Angeles]] *[[List of programs broadcast by MTV Australia]] == References == {{Wikipedia books|Bad Girls Club}} {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} == External links == * {{official website|http://www.oxygen.com/tvshows/badgirls/}} * [http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news.aspx?id=20060531oxygen01 Press release from Oxygen at The Futon Critic] * {{imdb title|0914829}} * {{tv.com|69075}} * [http://bostonist.com/2009/03/31/bostontv_bad_girls_whitney_does_pro.php Interview with Whitney after her departure from Season 3] {{Bad Girls Club}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bad Girls Club, The}} [[Category:2006 American television series debuts]] [[Category:American reality television series]] [[Category:Oxygen network shows]] [[Category:The Bad Girls Club| ]] [[Category:2000s American television series]] [[Category:2010s American television series]] [[Category:Television series by Bunim/Murray Productions]] [[es:El Club de las Chicas Malas]] [[simple:The Bad Girls Club]] [[sv:Stygga flickors klubb]]
